You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: industrial production recorded a monthly decline of 1.4 percent in january.\n                '}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: meanwhile, card spending further increased in the first quarter.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 22:34:33,606 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports an increase in card spending, which may indicate growing consumer demand and potential inflationary pressures, justifying a more hawkish approach."
}

inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in sum, current global supply conditions remain favorable for inflation.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that global supply conditions are favorable for inflation, implying that inflationary pressures are subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy."
}

prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: non-energy commodity prices, which remained almost flat in recent months, also decreased in october before returning to their relatively flat course in november.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 22:34:43,183 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence reports a decrease in non-energy commodity prices, suggesting a potential decrease in inflationary pressures, which may support an expansionary monetary policy stance."
}

stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: driven by international commodity prices, exchange rate developments and supply constraints, producer prices recorded a high rate of increase also in may, which spread across the sectors.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: annual inflation in the food and non-alcoholic beverages group rose by 1.04 points to 8.89% in november.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: having lost some momentum after mid-september, portfolio investments to turkey have been picking up again recently amid reduced geopolitical risks.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests a decrease in geopolitical risks, which could lead to increased investments and a more favorable economic environment, potentially supporting a dovish monetary policy stance."
}

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: monthly energy inflation was driven by the fuel item, which posted a price hike of 29.04%.\n                '}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, the inflation forecast uncertainty moderately increased due to uncertainties regarding the course of the pandemic.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 22:35:00,164 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports an increase in inflation forecast uncertainty due to pandemic-related uncertainties, but does not provide a clear bias towards tightening or easing policy."
}

inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: annual inflation in food and non-alcoholic beverages rose by 0.42 points to 14.12 percent.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports an increase in annual inflation in food and non-alcoholic beverages, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: on the other hand, uncertainties regarding oil prices and global markets pose an upside risk to inflation through the cost channel.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights potential upside risks to inflation, suggesting that the Central Bank of Turkey may need to adopt a tighter monetary policy stance to combat inflationary pressures."
}

stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: solid fuel, bottled gas and administered municipal water prices were up, whereas fuel prices remained flat due to the new sliding-scale tariff system.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in other services, amid reopening, annual inflation increased due to recreational and cultural services as well as maintenance and repair.\n                '}]

"justification": "The sentence reports an increase in annual inflation in certain services, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: increases in exports of goods translate into a decelerated deterioration in the current account deficit and improvement in core current account deficit indicators.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests an improvement in the current account deficit, which could lead to a weaker lira and looser monetary policy, supporting economic growth."

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: although investment remains
